para.text: Exhaust Hoods. All hoods over cooking surfaces shall comply with the requirements as provided in COMAR 10.15.03.
Unless otherwise indicated, all general requirements apply to both new construction and an existing nursing home.
Emergency Electrical Power.
The nursing home shall provide emergency electrical power.
Emergency power for the purpose of egress lighting and protection shall be as required by NFPA 101 Life Safety Code.
Other emergency lighting shall be as follows:
Nursing station;
Drug distribution station or unit dose storage;
A lighted area for emergency telephone use;
Boiler or mechanical room;
Kitchen;
Generator set location and switch gear location;
Elevator, if operable on emergency power;
Areas where life support equipment is used;
If applicable, lighting for the common area of refuge; and
If applicable, lighting in toilet rooms of the common area of refuge.
Emergency power shall be provided for the:
Nurses’ call system;
Duplex receptacles installed 50 feet apart in all corridors in resident areas or appropriately located duplex receptacles in the common area of refuge;
Telephone service with at least one telephone available for incoming and outgoing calls;
Fire pump;
Sewerage pump and sump pump;
Elevator, if required, for evacuation as referenced in NFPA 101 Life Safety Code;
Heating equipment, if applicable, to maintain a minimum temperature of 71°F or 22°C in the common areas of refuge;
Life support equipment;
Nonflammable medical gas systems;
Computer system, if applicable, to enable use of electronic medical records system; and
Refrigerated medication storage.
Common Area or Areas of Refuge.

The nursing home shall provide a common area or areas of refuge in an emergency situation if all resident rooms, day rooms, and toilet rooms are not tied into the emergency generator to provide heat and cooling.
The common area or areas of refuge:
Shall be at least 30 square feet per bed, not including corridors;
May not include toilet rooms in the 30 square feet per bed; and
Shall maintain a minimum temperature of 71°F or 22°C and a maximum temperature of 81°F or 27°C.
The nursing home shall provide heated toilet rooms adjacent to the common areas of refuge.
The nursing home shall provide a Department-approved written plan that:
Defines the specified area of refuge;
Outlines paths of egress from the common areas of refuge; and
Describes provisions for light, heat, food service, washing, and toileting residents.
Emergency Power Source.
The emergency power source shall be a generating set and prime mover located on the premises with automatic transfer.
The emergency generator shall:
In the event of failure of the normal electrical service, be activated immediately;
Come to full speed and load acceptance within 10 seconds;
Have a capacity of 48 hours of operation from fuel stored on-site; and
Be tested once a month, for at least 30 minutes under normal emergency nursing home connected load, and the test recorded in a permanent log book maintained for that purpose.
Size. Nursing care units may not exceed 60 beds. The Department may specify the numbers and types of personnel for each unit which exceeds 40 beds.
Common Space. The nursing home shall provide a living room for residents’ use with a sufficient number of reading lamps, tables, and comfortable chairs or sofas.
Service Areas Required.
Nurses’ Work Area.
The nurses’ work area shall be located on the unit and within easy view of corridors outside of residents’ rooms.
The Department may specify the location and size of a nurses’ work area which serves a nursing care unit exceeding 40 beds.
Nursing Care Unit.
A nursing care unit, regardless of size, including special care units, shall be equipped as described in this regulation.
A nursing care unit bathroom shall include:
A toilet, within the care unit, for the use of personnel; and
A hand-washing sink equipped with goose-neck spout, separate soap dispenser, and disposable paper towel dispenser.
A nursing care unit’s medicine shall be stored in accordance with the following procedures:
Shall be stored in a cabinet with locks;
Schedule II drugs shall be kept in a separately locked, securely fixed box or drawer in the medicine storage cabinet under two locks, keyed differently;
The medicine storage and preparation area shall be illuminated with at least 100 foot-candles at the work counter;
The preparation area shall include a small sink set into the counter or with drain boards and a biological refrigerator; and
The medicine storage cabinet, medicine preparation area, and biological refrigerator shall be under the direct visual control of the nursing or pharmacy staff.
Nurses' call system.
Charting desk and supplies.
Storage space for miscellaneous medical supplies which shall be protected from contamination.
A nursing care unit shall have sufficient space and equipment for medical records so that personnel can function effectively and maintain easily accessible records for all residents.
Medication Storage in Nursing Home.
The storage facility shall provide for the conditions listed in §C(3)(b)—(g) of this regulation when prescribed.

Cold — Any temperature at or below 46°F or 8°C. A refrigerator is a cold place in which the temperature is maintained thermostatically between 46°F and 59°F or 8°C and 15°C. A freezer is a cold place in which the temperature is maintained thermostatically between -4°F and -14°F or -20°C and -26°C.

Cool — Any temperature between 46°F and 59°F or 8°C and 15°. An article for which storage in a cool place is directed may, alternatively, be stored in a refrigerator, unless otherwise specified in the individual monograph.
Room Temperature — The temperature prevailing in a working area. Controlled room temperature is a temperature maintained thermostatically between 59°F and 86° F or 15°C and 30°C.
Warm — Any temperature between 86°F and 104°F or 30°C and 40°C.
Excessive Heat — Any temperature above 104°F or 40°C.
Protection from Freezing. The container label bears appropriate instructions to protect the product from freezing when freezing it may subject a product to:
Loss of strength or potency;
Risk of breakage of the container; or
Destructive alteration of the dosage form.

Storage under Non-specific Conditions. When no specific storage directions or limitations are provided in the individual monograph, the storage conditions shall include protection from moisture, freezing, and excessive heat.
Space for Storage of Linen. Capacity shall be provided for storing of at least two complete linen changes per bed. Clean linen shall be stored separately from unclean items.
Janitor Closet — New Construction.
A nursing unit shall contain at least one janitor closet containing a floor receptor or service sink and storage space for housekeeping equipment and supplies.
The janitor closet shall be equipped for hand washing.
The janitor closet shall be connected to mechanically operated exhaust ventilation.
The plumbing fixture for the utility or service sink within a janitor closet shall be provided with a back-flow prevention device.
Utility Rooms.
There shall be separate clean and soiled utility rooms in each nursing unit:
Accessible to the resident area;
Each having separate entrances; and
No more than 120 feet to the most remote resident bedroom.
The clean utility room shall contain:
A small sink equipped with gooseneck spout and wrist blades;
Soap and individual paper towels in a dispenser;
Adequate storage and work counter space for storage and assembly of supplies for nursing procedures; and
Clean linen stored and transported in covered containers, closed linen carts, or rooms exclusively provided for this purpose.
The soiled utility room shall contain:
Work counter with sink, gooseneck faucet, and wrist blades;
A small sink equipped with soap and individual paper towels in a dispenser;
Space for waste receptacles and soiled linen receptacles; provision for storing and transporting soiled linen in covered leakproof containers;
Equipment to clean and sanitize bedpans, urinals, and basins; and
Equipment for the disposal of liquid and semi-solid wastes and bodily fluids via the nursing home’s sanitary sewer connection or on-site sewage disposal system.

Culture Change Nursing Home. In a culture change nursing home, service areas shall be provided for resident care needs as approved by the Department. The culture change nursing home shall be required to have service areas that meet the specifications in this chapter for:
Clean storage;
Soiled holding;
Laundry;
Janitorial services; and
Medication storage.

Drinking Fountains. One public drinking fountain or comparable equipment as preapproved by the Department shall be provided on each floor, usable from a wheelchair. Alternative means to provide drinking water to residents, staff, and the general public may be used as approved by the Department.
Automated External Defibrillator.
A nursing home shall possess a functioning automated external defibrillator (AED).
As of July 1, 2020, a nursing home shall install a functioning AED unit.
Call System.
A nurse call system shall be installed and maintained in operating order in all nursing units.
A call system shall be maintained in a manner that will provide visible and audible signal communication between nursing service personnel and residents.
A call station shall provide readily accessible and detachable extension cords to each resident’s bed in the residents’ rooms at all times.
A call system shall have a visible signal above the door of each resident’s bedroom that shall be visible from all parts of the corridor.
A call system shall provide visual lights at corridor intersections, in multi-corridor nursing units.
A call system shall be provided in each resident’s bathroom and bathing area in locations accessible to the residents.
The call system shall enable residents in the rehabilitation area to summon rehabilitation staff.
The nurses’ call system shall require resetting at the station where the call originates.
Wireless Call Systems.
A call system that uses wireless pagers or other wireless communication devices may be used as an alternative system.
A wireless device shall:
Be issued to all assigned direct care staff; and
Receive signals originating from residents’ bedrooms, bathrooms, bathing areas, and therapy areas.
The use of an approved wireless call system shall eliminate the need to install call light indicators outside the residents’ bedrooms, bathrooms, bathing areas, and therapy areas.

A computer system with a monitor or other electronic display device may be installed to replace the call system annunciator, as long as it reveals the location where the signal originated and sounds an audible alert tone. Otherwise, a dedicated annunciator connected to the wireless call system will be needed.
An electrically powered call system shall be connected to the emergency power supply.
The sounding of the audible signal shall be continuous or intermittent until answered.
The audible signal may not be turned off at the nursing station.
The audible signal shall be loud enough to be heard at the nurses’ station.

Unless otherwise indicated, all general requirements apply to both new construction and an existing nursing home unless a waiver has been granted by the Office of Health Care Quality in accordance with Regulation .03G of this chapter.
Bedroom Accommodations.
Bedroom.
A resident’s room shall have direct access to an exit in accordance with the requirements applicable to nursing homes specified in NFPA 101 Life Safety Code.
A room that opens into the kitchen may not be used as a resident bedroom.
A room may not be used as a resident bedroom if it can only be reached by passing through a kitchen.
Residents may not occupy rooms extending below the ground level.
No more than four individuals may occupy a multiple occupancy bedroom.
Residents’ beds may not be located near radiators, registers, or sources of draft.

Adequate storage space shall be provided in each bedroom to allow each resident to keep necessary items of clothing, including items that need to be hung. Adequate storage space shall be provided for residents’ personal possessions, including the storage of seasonal clothing.
All occupants of any bedroom shall be of the same sex, except in the case of a two-bed room occupied by:
Siblings;
A parent and child;
A married couple; or
Consenting residents.
Bedroom — New Construction. A nursing home shall provide cubicle curtains and tracks in multiple occupancy bedrooms between beds to ensure privacy of residents.
Bedroom — Existing Construction. In an existing nursing home, curtains or screens shall be acceptable.
Floor and Window Space.
Floors.
A distance of at least 3 feet shall be maintained between each bed. Beds are to be placed so that all sides of the bed are at least 18 inches from heating units.
The following shall be considered a minimum allowance of floor space:
100 square feet, single-bed room; and
80 square feet, per bed, for multiple-bed rooms.
The following floor areas may not be included in the calculation of floor space:
Toilet rooms and bathing facilities;
Closets;
The floor area occupied by wardrobes, bureaus, or lockers, when permanently installed as part of walls or ceilings and as a permanent component of a bedroom;
HVAC equipment, including any steam, water, or electrical supply or return lines that may run parallel to the floor or interrupt the floor surface;
Support columns, pipe chases, or other structures, whether free-standing or as an integral part of a wall; and
The arc of any doors that open into the room, excluding closet doors.
The minimum horizontal dimensions of a bedroom shall be 10 feet to:
Facilitate the placement of beds as required in Regulation .44 of this chapter; and
Maintain a minimum clearance of 3 feet at the foot of the bed.

In an existing nursing home, the usable floor area for rooms having a bedroom shall have a finished ceiling height of 8 feet. For a bedroom that has sloping walls, only 50 percent of the floor area with a ceiling height between 4 feet and 7 feet, 6 inches, shall be credited, provided that at least 50 percent of the total area of the bedroom has a ceiling height of 8 feet.
Windows.

The window area within each bedroom shall be at least 10 square feet per bed. The window opening shall be at least 28 inches so that the total area equals 10 square feet per bed. This is to allow entry of fire fighters, removal of smoke, and emergency evacuation.
The maximum height from the floor to the top of a window sill shall be 44 inches above the finished floor.
A portable window air-conditioning unit may not block window space. The installation of a portable air-conditioning unit shall be approved by the:
Local fire authorities; and
Department.
If windows cannot be opened for ventilation, a central HVAC system shall be provided and maintained.

If windows can be opened, but the nursing home has concern over the window being opened due to resident safety issues and elopement, the window sash may be restricted by hardware as approved by the Department.
Furnishings.
Furnishings.
The nursing home shall provide residents with their own bed. The bed shall be at least 36 inches wide and be substantially constructed. Rollaway type beds, cots, or folding beds may not be used.
Bed.
Each bed provided shall be in good repair, with a clean and comfortable standard size mattress and foundation.
To avoid injury to the resident, the mattress and foundation shall fit the bed.
Clean linen and a clean, comfortable pillow shall be provided. Extra pillows shall be available.
Bedroom Furniture. A resident shall be provided with the following furnishings, which shall be convenient to the resident:
Bedside stand with a drawer;
Towel hanger;
A comfortable chair;
A chest of drawers with at least one locking drawer;
Enclosed space for hanging clothing;
A wall mirror in each room, unless contraindicated by physician’s order; and
A bedside lamp, over-bed lamp, or other directional light source for resident reading and bedside care.
Resident’s Personal Furnishings.
A nursing home shall develop policies and procedures to give residents the opportunity to use the resident’s own furnishings as detailed in this chapter.
The nursing home shall make its resident’s personal furnishing policies available for review by residents and the resident’s representative.

These policies shall address the condition of the personal furnishings, presence of insects or vermin, and overall safety to ensure that the use of the resident’s belongings does not create any safety or health issues.
Personal furnishings that are allowed shall be appropriate for the resident’s use.
Windows shall be provided with shades or draperies adequate to control glare and maintain privacy.
Each living room for residents’ use shall be provided with a sufficient number of reading lamps, tables, and comfortable chairs or sofas.
Furnishings — New Construction. A bedroom shall be provided with a hand-washing sink with both hot and cold running water unless a toilet or bathroom facility with a sink is connected to the bedroom.
Medication Storage Cabinets.
Medication storage cabinets with locks shall be permitted for the storage of resident medications that do not require refrigeration within a resident bedroom.

Controlled medications to be stored within medication storage cabinets in a resident’s room shall be held within a separate compartment that is locked and inside of the larger medication storage cabinet in that room.
Body-Holding Room — New Construction and Existing Nursing Home.
A body-holding room shall be equipped with ventilation by mechanical means at the same rate and specifications as designed for soiled linen sorting and storage areas.
A nursing home shall develop and implement a method for body-holding that minimizes the psychological effects on other residents.
Body-Holding Room — New Construction. A body-holding room shall be located to facilitate quiet and unobtrusive ingress and egress of bodies, convenient to the elevator and with an isolated exit.
Body-Holding Room — Existing Nursing Home. If a body-holding room is not provided, a holding area shall be designated that approximates the above conditions.
Bathing.
There shall be at least one separate room or compartment with a bathtub, shower, or other bathing device, as approved by the Department, for every 15 licensed beds.
The compartment shall be large enough to accommodate:
The resident;
A caregiver; and
A wheelchair, shower chair, or shower bed.
Toilets.
For every eight beds, there shall be at least one toilet enclosed in a separate room or stall.
Each floor shall have at least one toilet room large enough to:
Accommodate:
The resident;
A wheelchair; and
A caregiver; and
Permit toilet assistance or training.
Sinks.
For every four licensed beds, there shall be at least one hand-washing sink.
For hand-washing purposes, there shall be a towel dispenser and a supply of paper towels and soap dispenser adjacent to each sink.

section.heading: Equipment and Supplies for Bedside Care and Therapy.

para.text: Needs of Residents.
There shall be sufficient equipment to meet the needs of the residents admitted.
The administrator shall obtain specific items required for individual cases where requested by the attending physician or medical director.
The Department may require that the nursing home have specific types of equipment based on the needs of the residents.
A nursing home shall establish and enforce a written preventive maintenance program to ensure that all resident care and therapy equipment is maintained in safe operating condition.
Use of Hot Packs, Ice Packs, and Other Therapeutic Medical Devices.
Covers shall be placed on hot packs, ice packs and other temperature-related therapeutic medical devices before they are placed in a bed or on a resident.
The temperatures in the building, hot packs, and therapeutic equipment may not exceed 120°F or 49°C.
The use of hot and cold medical devices shall be:
Consistent with manufacturer’ guidelines and nursing home policies; and
Maintained and applied by trained staff.
Unless otherwise indicated, all general requirements apply to both new construction and an existing nursing home.
General Requirements.
Space.
A nursing home shall provide adequate space to:
Receive, examine, and treat residents;
Store supplies and equipment, including wheelchairs and stretchers; and
Provide office space for the employed personnel to work.
A nursing home shall allot 75 square feet for treatment area per resident, based on peak treatment schedules.
A nursing home shall plan and arrange space for shared use by physical therapy and occupational therapy staff and residents, if scheduling permits.
A nursing home may distribute space in the following manner:
Storage space shall comprise at least 10 percent of the area designated for exercise and rehabilitation; and
Office space shall be at least 110 square feet for one therapist, or 85 square feet per therapist if there are two or more.
Equipment.
Equipment shall allow for providing safe and effective resident care.

All electrical equipment shall be calibrated according to the manufacturer's guidelines and shall be serviced periodically as part of a preventive maintenance program. A sticker bearing the date of the most current inspection shall be affixed on each piece of equipment.
All electrical equipment shall be tested periodically for proper grounding, current leakage, and calibration where appropriate.
The operator’s instruction manual shall be available in a designated location or accessible electronically at all times.
All flammables shall be stored in compliance with NFPA 99 Health Care Facilities.
Adequate exhaust ventilation shall be provided when using vaporous materials or pollutants.
Toilet Facilities in Rehabilitation Area — New Construction.

A nursing home with rehabilitation areas shall provide a hand-washing sink and toilet which meet Guidelines for Design and Construction of Residential Health, Care, and Support Facilities standards for residents who use a wheelchair.
The nursing home shall be readily accessible to the residents receiving rehabilitative services.
Toilets and bathing rooms within a rehabilitation area shall be equipped with a nurse call system.

General Requirements. Resident Dining, Occupational Therapy, and Activities Program. The nursing home shall provide one or more attractively furnished areas of adequate size for resident dining, occupational therapy, and social activities. Activities space shall be of adequate size to meet the needs of the residents and shall be located on each floor occupied by residents.
Dining Area.
A nursing home shall provide dining areas large enough to accommodate all residents who eat there at the same time.
There shall be an allowance of at least 12 square feet per resident. This allowance shall be substantially increased proportionate to the number of residents who use a wheelchair.
The height of tables provided in dining areas shall accommodate each resident using a wheelchair.
Dayroom Area. Dayroom areas shall be provided that are:
Adequate for the residents located on each nursing care unit; and
Located convenient to the residents’ bedrooms.
Multi-purpose Room.

The nursing home shall provide a multi-purpose room for dining, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and social activities. There shall be sufficient space to accommodate all activities without interfering with each other.

The nursing home shall set aside areas for residents’ dining and recreation that total at least 30 square feet per licensed bed for the first 100 beds, plus 27 square feet per licensed bed for all beds in excess of 100.
Areas that meet this requirement may include:
Reception areas;
Lobbies, portion not required for egress per NFPA 101 Life Safety Code, as are applicable to nursing homes;
Hair care;
Salon rooms;
Resident gift shops;
Theater;
Auditorium;
Spiritual worship;
Meditation areas;
Dayrooms;
Dining areas;
Libraries; and
No more than 50 percent of the floor area of all occupational therapy and physical therapy areas, and other areas as approved by the Department.
General Requirements. Unless otherwise indicated, all general requirements apply to both new construction and an existing nursing home.
Food Service Department.
The size and location of the food service area shall comply with COMAR 10.15.03.
A catered or satellite system shall be covered by a contract approved by the Department.
The vendor providing the food shall have a valid food service permit.
Outside Service Entrance. A convenient outside service entrance shall exist to facilitate receiving food supplies and the disposal of waste.
Restriction — Entry to Kitchen or Serving Pantry. A toilet room or sleeping room may not open directly into any kitchen or serving pantry.
Limitations on Use of Kitchen. The kitchen may not be used as a passageway. It shall be used for no other purpose than activities connected with food service.
Janitor Closet or Service Area.
Janitor Closet — New Construction. A janitor closet or service alcove for the exclusive use of food service areas shall be provided in, or adjacent to, the dietetic service department.
The janitor closet or service alcove shall be:
Equipped with:
A utility sink;
Storage shelves; and
A rack for hanging brooms and mops; and
Connected to mechanically operated exhaust ventilation.
The plumbing fixture for the utility sink within a janitor’s closet shall be provided with an approved back-flow prevention device.
Space.

There shall be sufficient floor space in the food service department to permit all activities to function efficiently without overcrowding or increasing the risk for cross-contamination of food or equipment from soiled surfaces.
Minimum Space Requirements — New Construction.

tr.td: 132 square feet plus 12 square feet per licensed bed in excess of 11.
430 square feet plus 10 square feet per licensed bed in excess of 36.
1,070 square feet plus 8 square feet per licensed bed in excess of 100.

para.text: Space — Existing Nursing Home.
A nursing home that holds full licensure as of the adoption date of these regulations shall be considered to have an adequate size dietetic service department.
Renovations of all kitchens shall be approved by the Department, which will consider modification of the minimum space requirement based on space available, costs, and type of service.
Aisle space between working areas shall be at least 3 feet, and aisle space for main traffic shall be at least 5 feet wide.
Ceiling height shall be at least 9 feet.

If the licensed capacity of a nursing home is increased, or if meals are provided to anyone outside of the nursing home from the food service area of the nursing home, the nursing home shall provide an additional food service area in accordance with this chapter. The additional food service area required when meals are provided to anyone outside of the nursing home is to be calculated by using the total number of individuals to whom meals are provided.

The kitchen space requirement as described in this regulation does not apply to occasional special functions such as picnics or dinners for residents, volunteers, families, or community groups as long as the nursing home certifies to the Department that providing meals for a special function will not adversely affect or detract from the timely provision of meals to the nursing home’s residents.
Floor Pantries — New Construction.
There shall be at least one food service floor pantry per nursing care unit.
This area shall be of sufficient size to accommodate the equipment required for food preparation and service.
The equipment provided in food service floor pantries shall comply with the requirements of the local health department.
A food service floor pantry shall include the following:
Refrigerator;
Cabinets for dry storage and supplies;
Work space;
Sink for purposes other than hand-washing;
Hand-washing sink with soap dispenser and disposable paper towel dispenser; and

Except for trays that are assembled in the main kitchen and then distributed to the nursing care units, equipment to hold hot food if bulk foods are plated and served to the residents on the nursing care unit.
A food service floor pantry shall include the following additional equipment:
Toaster;
Ice-making machine or ice-storage container;
Work space for tray preparation;
Equipment to deliver completed trays;
Three-compartment sanitizing sink or dishwasher;
Cabinet for dry storage, supplies, and kitchenware; and
Storage for trays, tableware, flatware, and utensils.
Equipment for Food Preparation and Distributions.
Adequate equipment for preparation, serving, and distribution of food shall be provided.
A dumbwaiter, elevator, or ramp shall be provided in a nursing home of more than one story where more than eight residents above or below the kitchen level receive bedside tray service.
Equipment to protect food from dust or contamination and to maintain food at proper temperature shall be provided to transport food to the residents.
Dry Food Storage.
Food Storage Space.
Adequate space shall be provided to store food supplies.
The amount of storage space needed to store food depends on the frequency of deliveries.
It is recommended that 2 square feet per resident be provided and that the dry food storage area be located within easy access to the receiving area and the kitchen.
The storeroom shall be cool and well-ventilated.
All food supplies shall be stored off the floor and away from the wall to allow for cleaning.
Refrigerated Storage.
Adequate refrigerated storage, refrigerators, and frozen food storage cabinets shall be provided and regulated to maintain temperatures prescribed in COMAR 10.15.03.
Food in storage shall be arranged so that new food items are stored behind old food items.
The oldest foods shall be used first, known as the first in, first out method.
Mobile Food Carts.
All policies and procedures for the mobile food cart shall be approved by the Department and the nursing home’s local health department before implementation.
Policies and procedures shall address, at a minimum the following:
Identify how many staff members will assist with serving food items, pushing the mobile cart, and delivering meals to the residents;
Ensure proper food protection on three sides to protect the food;
Maintain proper temperature control, hot food at a minimum of 135°F and cold food maintained at a maximum of 41°F;
Record of temperatures before serving meals on each individual unit;
Ensure proper food temperatures; and
Hand washing.
The hand washing policy and procedures referenced in §L(2)(f) of this regulation shall include the following:
Use of a hand sanitizer in lieu of proper hand washing is not permitted;
Bare hands may not have direct contact with ready-to-eat food;
Hand washing shall be done before starting meal service on each individual unit;
When and at what location hand washing will be done;
Hand washing may not be done in resident rooms;
Access to a hand washing sink may not require the opening of a door;
The hand washing sink shall be in a central, unobstructed location;
Mobile hand sinks are acceptable as long as a written procedure to meet sanitation requirements is developed;
The hand sink shall be supplied with hot and cold water under pressure;
The unit shall be supplied with adequate waste containers to hold dirty water until dumping is done; and
The written procedure shall include the disposal of the dirty water.
Unless otherwise indicated, all general requirements apply to both new construction and an existing nursing home.
Administrative Areas — New Construction.

A nursing home shall provide a separate room or rooms for the administrator and administrative support staff. Sufficient areas shall be provided to accommodate all necessary office furniture, files, and other equipment and enable the safe storage of residents’ valuables.
In new construction, separate locker rooms and a toilet facility shall be provided for male and female employees in each nursing home.
Administrative Areas — Existing Nursing Homes.
The nursing home shall provide an administrative area that is suitable for conducting business or discussing problems privately with the resident’s representative.
The nursing home shall provide a sufficient number of lockers that can be locked securely for all employees working at any one time, and shall provide for the employee use of toilet facilities.
Lobby Area — New Nursing Home. A nursing home shall provide a lobby area that shall have:
Public toilets for both sexes, either separate or unisex, located conveniently to this area;
Access to telephone; and
Drinking fountains or other drinking water dispensers that meet Guidelines for Design and Construction of Residential Health, Care, and Support Facilities.
Employee Facilities — New Construction. In new construction, separate locker rooms and toilet facilities shall be provided for male and female employees in each facility.
Employee Facilities — Existing Facilities. An existing nursing home shall:
Have a sufficient number of lockers that can be locked securely for all employees working at any one time; and
Provide for the employee use of toilet facilities at a convenient location.

section.heading: Housekeeping Services, Pest Control, and Laundry.

para.text: General Requirements. Unless otherwise indicated, all general requirements apply to both new construction and an existing nursing home.
Staff. Sufficient housekeeping and maintenance personnel shall be employed to maintain the interior and exterior of the facility in a safe, clean, orderly, and attractive manner.
Cleanliness and Maintenance.
The building and all its parts and facilities shall be kept in good repair, neat, and attractive. The safety and comfort of the residents shall be the primary consideration.
All walls, floors, ceilings, windows, and fixtures shall be kept clean. Interior walls and floors shall be of a type to allow frequent and easy cleaning.
The nursing home shall be kept free of unnecessary accumulations of personal possessions, boxes, trunks, suitcases, papers, unused furniture, bed clothing, linens, bric-a-brac, and similar items.
Storage areas shall be:
Kept clean and orderly; and
Readily accessible for:
Housekeeping;
Maintenance; and
Pest control servicing.
The grounds shall be kept clean, neat, attractive, and free of hazards.
Pest Control. The nursing home shall:
Be maintained free of insects and rodents by operation of an active pest-control program, either by use of maintenance personnel or by contract with a pest-control company;
Use and store toxic and flammable insecticides and rodenticides with care;
Ensure that usage of toxic and flammable insecticides and rodenticides conforms to the U.S. Environmental Protection Administration and Maryland Department of Agriculture requirements;
Be protected to prevent the entry and harborage of rodents and insects;
Install and effectively maintain:
Screen doors that fit tightly when closed;
Easily adjusted closely fitted window screens;
Rat-proofing devices; or
Other approved deterrents; and
Effectively protect all openings to the outside against the entry of insects by:
Closed doors;
Closed windows; or
Other means.
Laundry Services.
A nursing home shall provide laundry service, whether on-site or off-site.
Laundry service shall be provided to meet the residents’ needs.
All laundry shall be processed and handled in a manner that prevents the spread of infections. Staff working in laundry shall be given personal protective equipment, including:
Disposable gloves;
Masks; and
Body coverings.
All laundry shall be processed through the use of sufficiently hot water, chemical agents, or a combination of the both, to remove or destroy infectious biological materials.
Clean and Soiled Areas.
There shall be a physical separation between the clean and soiled areas.
The soiled area shall allow for sorting and washing soiled laundry.
The clean area shall allow for drying and folding of clean laundry.
All soiled areas within a laundry shall be connected to mechanically operated exhaust ventilation.

The system provided in laundries may not allow the spread of airborne contaminants to other parts of the nursing home that are occupied by residents, staff not working in the laundry, and the general public.

The plumbing fixtures for all water supply connections to washing machines and the plumbing fixtures for all utility sinks shall have an integrated atmospheric vacuum breaker or other approved back-flow prevention devices.
Each comprehensive care facility and extended care facility shall establish and maintain a resident care management system.
The resident care management system shall consist of three related components:
Resident status assessment and data gathering;
Care planning; and
Actions in response to care plan approaches.

A nursing home shall use the following forms and procedures for resident assessment as described in the CMS Manual System, Pub. 100-07 State Operations Provider Certification and in the CMS Long-term Care Facility Resident Assessment Instrument 3.0 User’s Manual:

The Minimum Data Set (MDS) version as determined by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, in Transmittal No. 22, referenced in §B of this regulation.
MDS Care Area Assessment process; and
Care plans.
The nursing home shall complete all assessments in accordance with the provisions of 42 CFR §483.20, as amended.

A nursing home certified for participation in Medicare or Medicaid shall complete and electronically submit the assessment to the Quality Improvement and Evaluation System (QIES) Assessment Submission and Processing (ASAP) system. The assessment shall:
Use a standard record layout format;
Use a data dictionary as identified by the automated data processing requirements; and
Pass standardized edits as defined by CMS and the State.
A federally certified nursing home shall:
Encode assessment data as specified in the CMS Long-term Care Facility Resident Assessment Instrument 3.0 User’s Manual; and
Transmit assessment data as specified in the CMS Long-term Care Facility Resident Assessment Instrument 3.0 User’s Manual except as excluded in §E of this regulation.

A nursing home licensed as a nursing home but not certified for participation in the Medicare or Medicaid Program shall comply with the CMS Manual System, Pub. 100-07 State Operations Provider Certification, and with RAI instructions in the CMS Long-term Care Facility Resident Assessment Instrument 3.0 User’s Manual, except that data may not be submitted electronically to the Department.
An interdisciplinary team shall complete or revise as necessary a resident-specific care plan for each resident within 7 calendar days following completion of assessments, including:
Admission assessment;
Annual assessment;
Quarterly assessment; and
Significant change in the resident’s condition.
Care Plan Meeting. The nursing home shall, with the resident’s consent:
Give an interested and appropriate family member or resident’s representative 7 calendar days advance notice, in writing, of the location, date, and time of a care planning conference for a resident;
Strive to accommodate the schedules of invited family members and resident’s representatives when scheduling care plan meetings; and
Include an invitation for the family member or resident’s representative to attend the conference.

The nursing home shall hold the care planning conference not later than 7 calendar days after completing the assessment, but may hold the conference sooner if agreed to by the resident, a family member, or a resident’s representative.
Organization of Care Plan.

Resident’s problems and needs shall be identified, based upon the interdisciplinary assessment. The care plan shall address all of the resident’s special care requirements necessary to improve or maintain the resident’s status. The interdisciplinary team shall incorporate resident input into the care plan.

The team shall establish goals for each problem or need identified, or a combination thereof. The goals shall be realistic, practical, and tailored to the resident’s needs. Goal outcomes shall be measurable in time or degree, or both.
Approaches to accomplishing each goal shall be established. Approaches shall indicate the work to be done, who is to do it, and how frequently it is to be done.
Disciplines shall update the care plans as the resident's assessment warrants, but not less than quarterly.
Availability of Resident Care Plan. Resident care plans shall be readily available for use by all health care personnel.
The facility shall establish a skin care record documenting skin, hair, and nail condition on admission, if any abnormal conditions exist.
The staff shall document progress of the condition or conditions weekly until the condition or conditions have healed.
At any time that a skin condition persists for more than 7 days, staff shall add the condition to the skin record.
Nursing Home Responsibilities.

A nursing home shall conduct or arrange a geriatric nursing assistant training program for unlicensed personnel assigned to direct resident care duties. The Maryland Board of Nursing shall approve the geriatric nursing assistant training program curriculum.
A nursing home may not employ an individual as a geriatric nursing assistant until the individual has successfully completed a competency evaluation approved by the Maryland Board of Nursing.

A geriatric nursing assistant is deemed to satisfy the requirements of this chapter if that individual has successfully completed a training program approved by the State before July 1, 1990, or has been “grandfathered” under previous regulations.
Other persons hired as geriatric nursing assistants shall complete an approved geriatric nursing assistant training program within 120 days of employment.
The nursing home shall:
Record the satisfactory completion of the program in each employee’s personnel record; and
Give the employee a certificate signed by the program’s teacher or trainer as evidence of completion of the program.
Course Structure.

The geriatric nursing assistant training program shall consist of 75 hours or more, and include at least 37.5 hours of classroom instruction and at least 37.5 hours of supervised clinical experience in long-term care.
The course content shall adhere to the geriatric nursing assistant training program curriculum approved by the Maryland Board of Nursing.
A facility may use a paid feeding assistant who has successfully completed a State-approved training course as described in §E of this regulation.
Supervision.
A paid feeding assistant shall work under the supervision of a licensed nurse.
In an emergency, when the resident is fed in the resident's room, a paid feeding assistant shall use the resident call system to call a supervisory nurse for help.
A nursing home that uses a paid feeding assistant shall ensure that the paid feeding assistant feeds only residents who do not have complicated feeding conditions including, but not limited to:
Difficulty swallowing;
Choking;
Recurrent lung aspiration; or
Tube or parenteral intravenous feedings.
Protocol. The nursing home shall develop a protocol for selecting residents who are appropriate for feeding by a paid feeding assistant. The nursing home shall select eligible residents based on the:
Charge nurse's current assessment of the resident;
The resident's latest Minimum Data Set (MDS) assessment; and
The resident's plan of care.
State-Approved Training. A State-approved training course for paid feeding assistants shall consist of at least 8 hours of training that includes:
Feeding techniques;
Assistance with feeding and hydration;
Communication and interpersonal skills;
Appropriate responses to resident behavior;
Safety and emergency procedures, including the Heimlich maneuver;
Infection control;
Resident rights;
Recognizing changes in a resident's behavior that are inconsistent with the resident's normal behavior and the importance of reporting these changes to a supervisory nurse; and
Successful completion of a two-part test that includes a:
Written test with a passing score of 80 percent; and
Demonstration of proper feeding skills performed on a resident while being observed.
The feeding assistant training may be taught by a:
Registered nurse and supplementary professional instructors;
Licensed dietitian-nutritionist;
Licensed physical therapist;
Licensed speech therapist; or
Licensed occupational therapist.
The facility shall maintain a record of all paid feeding assistants who have successfully completed a feeding assistance course.
A nursing home shall establish an effective quality assurance program that includes components described in this regulation and Regulation .65 of this chapter.
The nursing home shall appoint a qualified individual to manage quality assurance activities within the nursing facility.
The nursing home shall establish a quality assurance committee that includes at least:
The nursing home director of nursing;
The nursing home administrator;
A social worker;
The nursing home medical director;
A dietitian-nutritionist; and
A geriatric nursing assistant at the nursing home.
The Quality Assurance Committee. The quality assurance committee shall:
Designate an individual to oversee committee activities;
Meet monthly to carry out quality assurance activities;
Help develop and approve the nursing home’s quality assurance plan;
Submit the quality assurance plan to the Department’s Office of Health Care Quality at the time of initial application for licensure;
Submit any changes to the quality assurance plan to the Office of Health Care Quality within 30 days of the changes;
Review and approve the facility's quality assurance plan at least yearly; and
Prepare monthly reports for the ombudsman, family council, and residents' council.

Quality Assurance Records. For the purposes of ensuring implementation and effectiveness of the quality assurance program, the facility shall make quality assurance records and documents available to the Office of Health Care Quality.
Quality Assurance Committee — Non-members. Anyone not on the committee shall be informed of how to present and submit concerns to:
The committee;
A member of the resident council; or
A member of the family council if one exists.
The nursing home’s quality assurance committee shall develop and implement a quality assurance plan that includes procedures for:
Concurrent review;
Ongoing monitoring;
Resident complaints;
Accidents and incidents; and
Abuse and neglect.
Concurrent Review. The quality assurance plan shall include:
The procedures for conducting concurrent review of each resident including:
Criteria to determine any change in a resident's condition;
A method to document the concurrent review; and
Identification of the licensed nurse or nurses conducting the concurrent review;
The procedures to evaluate clinical data for any resident with a change in condition including at least:
Medications;
Laboratory values;
Intake and output;
Skin breakdown;
Noted weights;
Appetite;
Injuries resulting from accidents or incidents; and
Any other relevant parameters that may affect the resident's physical or mental status;
Procedures to take action when there is a change in the resident’s condition, including:
Communicating changes to the director of nursing or the resident’s attending physician; and
Changing the resident’s plan of care as necessary; and
Procedure for referring data to the quality assurance committee, when appropriate.
Ongoing Monitoring. The quality assurance plan shall include:
A description of the measurable criteria for ongoing monitoring of all aspects of resident care including:
Medication administration;
Prevention of pressure ulcers, dehydration, and malnutrition;
Nutritional status and weight loss or weight gain;
Accidents and injuries;
Unexpected death; and
Changes in physical or mental status;
The methodology for collecting data;
The methodology for evaluating and analyzing data to determine trends and patterns;
A description of the thresholds and performance parameters that represent acceptable care for the measured criteria;
Time frames for referral to the quality assurance committee;
A description of the plan for follow-up to determine effectiveness of the recommendations; and
A description of how the quality assurance activities will be documented.
Resident Complaints. The quality assurance plan shall include:
A description of a complaint process that effectively addresses resident and family concerns including:
The designated person or persons and their phone numbers to receive complaints and concerns;
The method to be used to acknowledge complaints received; and
The time frames for investigating complaints, depending on the nature or seriousness of the complaint;
A description of a logging system that will be used including the:
Name of the complainant;
Date the complaint was received;
Nature of the complaint; and
Date that the complainant was notified of the disposition or resolution of the complaint; and
The procedures for:
Notifying residents of their right to file a complaint with the Office of Health Care Quality;
Informing residents, families, or guardians of the complaint process upon admission; and
Posting the complaint process or making it available without the need to request it.
Accidents and Injuries. The quality assurance plan shall include:
A definition of accident and injury that is appropriate to the type of resident served by the nursing home;
A description of the process for reporting accidents and injuries including:
Who shall report incidents;
The time frame for reporting incidents; and
The procedure for reporting incidents;
A policy statement that ensures that incidents can be reported without fear of reprisal;
A description of how internal investigations of accidents and injuries will be handled including:
Assessment of any injury;
Interview of the resident, staff, and any witnesses;
Review of any relevant records including the resident's medical records, discharge summary, hospital records, etc.; and
Time frames for conducting the investigation;
A description of the process for notifying a family or guardian about the incident;
A description of the process for the ongoing evaluation of patterns and trends in accidents and injuries; and
A description of how relevant information will be referred to the quality assurance committee.
Abuse and Neglect. The quality assurance plan shall include:
The process for implementing COMAR 10.07.09.15 concerning abuse of residents;
A description of the process for providing immediate notification to the family, guardian, or responsible party about the incident;
A description of the process for the ongoing evaluation of validated incidents of abuse and neglect to determine patterns and trends; and
A description of how relevant information will be referred to the quality assurance committee.
The facility shall develop and implement a written plan to provide for the smooth and orderly transfer of residents if the facility closes.
The plan for relocation shall include:
A description of how residents, families, or guardians will be notified and by whom;
Sample letters and other documents that will be used during a closure;
Procedures for notifying Medicaid and other payment sources;
Procedures for notifying the Office of Health Care Quality; and
A mechanism to ensure the safe and orderly transfer of residents that takes into account:
Roommates, medical care, religious affiliation, geographical location and payer source;
Proper assessment and identification of any special needs;
Transfer of medical information and records; and
Transfer of personal property.
A nursing home shall post a notice on each floor or unit of the nursing home, for each shift, a notice that gives the ratio of licensed and unlicensed staff to residents.
The posting on each floor shall include:
Names of the staff members on duty and the room numbers of the residents to whom each is assigned;
Name of the charge nurse or person who is in charge of the unit;
If the person in charge is not a registered nurse, the name of the registered nurse responsible for the unit; and
Name of the medicine aide or person responsible for medication administration.
The posting shall be on a form provided or approved by the Department.
A record of the posting shall be retained for 1 year.
If a deficiency exists, the Department, in addition to the sanctions set forth in this regulation and Regulations .67—.74 of this chapter, may:
Restrict the number of residents the nursing facility may admit in accordance with Health-General Article, §19-328, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Require the establishment of an escrow account in accordance with Health-General Article, §19-362, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Direct the licensee to correct the deficiencies in a specific manner or within a specific time frame, or both, to protect the health and welfare of residents;
Enter into an agreement with the licensee establishing certain conditions for continued operation, including time limits for compliance; and

In accordance with Health-General Article, §19-1405, Annotated Code of Maryland, appoint an independent State monitor who is qualified on the basis of education and experience to oversee correction of the deficiencies.
State Monitor.
The duties of the State monitor shall be specified in a written agreement between the Department and the State monitor and shall include but are not limited to:
Conducting periodic on-site inspections to assess a nursing facility's compliance with State and federal regulations;
Making recommendations to achieve compliance with State and federal regulations; and

Issuing written reports to the Department and the nursing home, detailing the findings of the on-site inspections and the status of requirements and recommendations for the nursing home to achieve compliance.

The State monitor shall function for a period of time specified by the Department. The facility may request rescission or modification of the duration of the State monitor's appointment at intervals of not less than 120 days from the date of appointment.
The State monitor may not be an employee of the Department.
The State monitor's salary shall be:
Paid directly by the nursing facility; and
At least equivalent to the prevailing salary paid by nursing facilities for an individual with similar education and experience.
If the Secretary determines that the licensee has violated a condition or requirement of an imposed sanction, the Secretary may revoke the license as permitted by applicable law.

A licensee that disagrees with the imposition of a sanction under §A(1) or (5) of this regulation may appeal the Secretary’s action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .78 of this chapter. A licensee that disagrees with the imposition of a sanction under §A(2) of this regulation may appeal the Secretary’s action in accordance with Health-General Article, §§19-364 and 19-367, Annotated Code of Maryland.
When the Department determines that a deficiency or deficiencies exist, the Department shall notify the nursing facility of the deficiency or deficiencies and may either:
Mandate a staffing pattern which specifies the number of personnel or personnel qualifications, or both; or
Permit the facility the opportunity to correct the deficiencies by a specific date.
If the facility does not correct the deficiency or deficiencies, the Department has the authority to specify the number of personnel or personnel qualifications, or both.
The facility shall comply with the Department's mandated staffing pattern and notify the Department, in writing, when the staffing pattern has been implemented.

A mandated staffing pattern shall be in effect for the period of time specified by the Department. A facility may request rescission or modification of the staffing pattern at intervals of not less than 60 days from the date of imposition of the staffing pattern.

A facility has the right to appeal a mandated staffing pattern in accordance with State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland. However, the mandated staffing pattern shall be maintained during the pendency of the appeal.
A civil money penalty may be imposed when:
A deficiency exists; or
An ongoing pattern of deficiencies exist in a nursing facility.
In determining whether a civil money penalty is to be imposed, the Department shall consider the following factors:
The number, nature, and seriousness of the deficiencies;
The extent to which the deficiency or deficiencies are part of an ongoing pattern during the preceding 24 months;
The degree of risk to the health, life, or safety of the residents of the nursing facility caused by the deficiency or deficiencies;
The efforts made by, and the ability of, the nursing facility to correct the deficiency or deficiencies;
A nursing facility's prior history of compliance in general and specifically with reference to the cited deficiencies; and
Such other factors as justice may require.
When the Department determines that a deficiency or an ongoing pattern of deficiencies exists, the Department shall notify the nursing facility of the deficiency or deficiencies and may:
Impose a per day civil money penalty until sustained compliance has been achieved;
Permit the facility the opportunity to correct the deficiencies by a specific date; or
Impose a per instance civil money penalty for each instance of violation.

When the Department permits a facility the opportunity to correct the deficiencies by a specific date, and the facility fails to comply with this requirement, the Department may impose a per day civil money penalty for each day of violation until correction of the deficiency or deficiencies has been verified and sustained compliance has been maintained.
When a civil money penalty is imposed, the Department shall issue an order which includes the:
Deficiency or deficiencies on which the order was based;
Amount of civil money penalty to be imposed; and
Manner in which the amount of civil money penalty was calculated.
An order issued pursuant to §E of this regulation is void unless issued within 60 days of the inspection or reinspection at which the deficiency or deficiencies are identified.

section.heading: Civil Money Penalties — Amount of Penalty.

para.text: A civil money penalty imposed under this chapter for potential for more than minimal harm deficiencies may not exceed:
$10,000 per instance; or
$1,000 per day for an ongoing pattern of deficiencies until correction of the deficiencies has been verified and sustained compliance has been maintained.
A civil money penalty imposed under this chapter for actual harm deficiencies may not exceed:
$10,000 per instance; or
$5,000 per day for an ongoing pattern of deficiencies until correction of the deficiencies has been verified and sustained compliance has been maintained.
A civil money penalty imposed under this chapter for a serious and immediate threat may not exceed:
$10,000 per instance; or
$10,000 per day for an ongoing pattern of deficiencies until correction of the deficiencies has been verified and sustained compliance has been maintained.
In setting the amount of a civil money penalty, the Department shall consider the following factors:
The number, nature, and seriousness of the deficiencies;
The degree of risk to the health, life, or safety of the residents of the nursing facility caused by the deficiency or deficiencies;
The efforts made by, and the ability of, the nursing facility to correct the deficiency or deficiencies;
Current federal guidelines for civil money penalties;
Whether the amount of the proposed civil money penalty will jeopardize the financial ability of the nursing facility to continue operating as a nursing facility;
A nursing facility's prior history of compliance; and
Such other factors as justice may require.

section.heading: Civil Money Penalties — Effective Date and Duration of Penalty.

para.text: Per Instance Civil Money Penalty. The effective date may be as early as the date that the deficiency or deficiencies upon which the civil money penalty is based first occurred.
Per Day Civil Money Penalty.
The daily civil money penalty starts to accrue as of the date of the visit that identifies the deficiency or deficiencies upon which the civil money penalty is based.

The accrual of the daily civil money penalty ceases when correction of the deficiency or deficiencies upon which the civil money penalty was based has been verified and the facility has maintained sustained compliance.

section.heading: Civil Money Penalties — Payment of Penalty/Establishment of Escrow Account.

para.text: A civil money penalty payment is due 15 calendar days after:
The time period for requesting a hearing has expired and a request for hearing was not received; or

Receipt of a written request from the facility to waive its right to a hearing and reduce the amount of the civil money penalty by 40 percent provided the written request is received by the Department within 30 calendar days of the Department's order imposing the civil money penalty.

Within 15 days of the request for an appeal by a nursing facility, the nursing facility shall deposit the amount of the civil money penalty in an interest-bearing escrow account. If a per day civil money penalty is in effect at the time the escrow account is established, the amount owed on that date shall be deposited into the escrow account. The nursing facility shall bear any cost associated with establishing the escrow account, and the account shall be titled in the name of the nursing facility and the Maryland Department of Health as joint owners.
When the Secretary issues the final decision of the Department:

If the decision upholds the imposition of the full civil money penalty, the escrow funds, in addition to the amount of any per day civil money penalty that has accrued after the initial deposit into the escrow account, shall be released to the Department within 15 days from the date of the decision;

If the decision upholds the imposition of a civil money penalty, but reduces the amount of the civil money penalty, the amount due the Department shall be released to the Department with accrued interest within 15 days of the date of the decision and the balance will be released to the nursing facility within 15 days of the date of the decision; or
If the decision reverses the imposition of the civil penalty, the escrow funds shall be released to the nursing facility with accrued interest within 15 days of the decision.

If a facility does not release or pay the civil money penalty to the Department after the Secretary has issued a final decision upholding the civil money penalty and after notice to the facility, the State may deduct the amount of the civil money penalty from any sum that is then or later owed by the State to the facility, pursuant to State Finance and Procurement Article, §7-222, Annotated Code of Maryland.

A licensee aggrieved by the imposition of a civil money penalty may appeal the action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Secretary has the burden of proof with respect to the imposition of civil money penalties.
The Office of Administrative Hearings shall render a decision within 10 working days of the hearing.

A person maintaining or operating a nursing home without a license is guilty of a misdemeanor, and, on conviction, is liable for a fine of not more than $1,000 for the first offense and not more than $10,000 for each subsequent conviction in accordance with Health-General Article, §19-358, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Each day that the nursing home continues to operate without a license after the first conviction is a subsequent offense and may subject the operator to further criminal prosecution.

A person maintaining and operating a nursing home that is in violation of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor, and, on conviction, shall be fined not more than $1,000 under the authority of Health-General Article, §19-359, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Each day that the nursing home operates after the first conviction, without correction of the cited violation, is considered a subsequent offense and may subject the operator to further prosecution.

The Secretary may immediately suspend a license on finding that the public health, safety, or welfare imperatively requires emergency action pursuant to State Government Article, §10-405(b), Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Department shall deliver a written notice to the nursing facility:
Informing the nursing facility of the emergency suspension;
Giving the reasons for the action and the regulation or regulations with which the licensee has failed to comply that forms the basis for the emergency suspension; and
Notifying the nursing facility of its right to request a hearing and to be represented by counsel.
The filing of a hearing request does not stay the emergency action.
When a license is suspended by emergency action:
The nursing facility shall immediately return the license to the Department; and

The licensee shall notify the residents or representatives of the residents of the suspension and make every reasonable effort to assist them in making arrangements for transfer to other appropriate living arrangements.
In the event of an emergency suspension, the Department may assist in the relocation of residents.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary's action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .59 of this chapter.

The Office of Administrative Hearings shall conduct a hearing as provided in Regulation .59 of this chapter and issue a proposed decision within 10 business days of the close of the hearing record. Exceptions may be filed by an aggrieved person pursuant to COMAR 10.01.03. The Secretary shall make a final decision pursuant to COMAR 10.01.03.
If the Secretary's final decision does not uphold the emergency suspension, the nursing facility may resume operation.

Denial or Revocation of License. The Secretary, for cause shown, may notify the nursing facility of the decision to revoke or deny the nursing facility's license. The denial or revocation shall be stayed if a hearing is requested.
The Department shall notify the nursing facility in writing of the following:
The effective date of the denial or revocation;
The reason for the denial or revocation;
The regulations with which the licensee has failed to comply that form the basis for the denial or revocation;
That the nursing facility is entitled to a hearing if requested, and to be represented by counsel;
That the nursing facility shall stop providing services on the effective date of the denial or revocation if the nursing facility does not request a hearing;
That the denial or revocation shall be stayed if a hearing is requested; and
That the nursing facility is required to surrender its license to the Department if the denial or revocation is upheld.

The licensee shall notify the residents or residents' representatives of any final denial or revocation and make every reasonable effort to assist them in making other living arrangements. The Department may assist in the relocation of residents.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary's action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .59 of this chapter.

A request for a hearing shall be filed with the Office of Administrative Hearings, with a copy to the Office of Health Care Quality of the Department, not later than 30 days after receipt of notice of the Secretary's action. This request shall include a copy of the Secretary's action.
A hearing requested under this chapter shall be conducted in accordance with:
State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland;
COMAR 28.02.01; and
The burden of proof is as provided in COMAR 10.01.03.28.
Unless otherwise stated in this chapter, the Office of Administrative Hearings shall issue a proposed decision within the time frames set forth in COMAR 28.02.01.
The aggrieved person may file exceptions as provided in COMAR 10.01.03.35.
A final decision by the Secretary shall be issued in accordance with COMAR 10.01.03.35.
The Department shall establish a health care quality account in the Department.
The health care quality account shall be funded by civil money penalties paid by nursing homes.
The Department shall use funds from the health care quality account to improve the quality of care in nursing facilities.
Expenditure of funds may include, but are not limited to the following:
Funding for the establishment and operation of a demonstration project;
A grant award;
Relocation of residents in crisis situations;
Provision of educational programs to nursing facilities, the Office of Health Care Quality, other government, professional, or advocacy agencies, and consumers; and
Any other purpose that will directly improve quality of care.
Suggestions for the use of funds may be submitted to the Department from:
Members of the public;
Advocacy organizations;
Government agencies;
Professional organizations including trade associations;
Nursing homes; and
Nursing home associations.
Decision on Expenditure of Funds.
The Department, in its sole discretion, shall decide how to spend funds from the health care quality account.

The Department's decision to spend funds or not to spend funds for a specific project or purpose is not a contested case as defined in State Government Article, §10-202(d), Annotated Code of Maryland, and therefore is not subject to appeal.
A licensee shall have financial resources in accordance with this regulation in order to:
Satisfy obligations; and
Ensure at all times the delivery of essential care and services, such as nursing, dietary services, or utilities.

A licensee shall notify the Secretary of significant adverse changes in financial condition which reasonably could be anticipated to adversely affect the delivery of essential care and services. These adverse changes include, but are not limited to, the following situations:

The facility fails to maintain the facility's utilities or a quantity of supplies, including nursing, dietary, pharmaceutical, or other care and service supplies, sufficient to meet the needs of the residents;
The facility is unable to meet its employee payroll or benefits obligations;

The license holder or entity legally authorized to act on behalf of the license holder receives notice that a judgment or tax lien of at least $5,000 has been filed, recorded, or levied against the facility or any of the assets of the facility or the license holder and the judgment or tax lien is not satisfied, or an appropriate extension has not been obtained, within 30 days after receipt of the notice;

A financial institution refuses to honor facility-operation-related checks or other financial instruments issued by the license holder or entity legally authorized to act on behalf of the license holder, and:
The cumulative amount of the checks or financial instruments is $5,000 or more; and

The checks or financial instruments are not honored or replaced to the satisfaction of the holders of the instruments within 10 working days after the holders have notified the license holder, operator, administrator, manager, or the person authorized to issue the instrument of the dishonored items;

The license holder, or entity legally authorized to act on behalf of the license holder fails to make timely payments of any facility-related tax of at least $1,000, and fails to satisfy the tax within 30 working days after the date the tax becomes delinquent;

The license holder, owner of 25 percent of the license holder's assets, or facility management company files a voluntary bankruptcy petition, or a creditor files an involuntary bankruptcy petition against the facility management company, license holder, or owner of 25 percent or greater of the license holder's assets;
A court appoints a bankruptcy trustee for the facility;
A person seeking appointment of a receiver for the facility files a petition for the appointment of a receiver for the facility in any jurisdiction;

The license holder, or person legally authorized to act on behalf of the license holder is unable to meet conditions of a facility-operation-related loan or material debt covenant unless the loan or material debt covenant has been waived or cured, and that inability has led to a recall by the issuing entity; or

The license holder, or entity legally authorized to act on behalf of the license holder, is delinquent on more than $5,000 of facility-related contractual obligations or vendor contracts that affect essential care and services for residents and has not cured the delinquency within 10 working days after receipt of notice from the creditor or creditors to pay the debt.

The license holder shall notify the Secretary in writing of a significant adverse change in its financial condition as required by §B of this regulation within 72 hours after the license holder becomes aware of, or reasonably should have become aware of, the change in its financial condition.
The license holder's notice required by §B of this regulation shall include a description of:
The specific significant adverse change in financial condition;
How the significant adverse change in financial condition affects or may affect the license holder's ability to deliver essential care and services; and
The actions the license holder has taken to address the significant adverse change in financial condition.

The license holder shall fax, email, or hand-deliver the notice required in §B of this regulation to the Department's Office of Health Care Quality, and the notice shall be kept on file with a copy of the delivery confirmation.

The license holder shall provide any other information, unless prohibited under applicable laws, requested by the Office of Health Care Quality to substantiate continued compliance with the requirements of this regulation within 30 days after the request. Failure to comply with the requirements of this regulation may result in the Secretary imposing one or more sanctions, as appropriate, from Regulations .51—.58 of this chapter against the facility.
The information submitted pursuant to §D of this regulation is confidential and may not be disclosed without the consent of the licensee.
Unless disclosure of the information is otherwise prohibited by applicable law, the provisions of §G of this regulation do not apply to:
The holder of a license that has been suspended or revoked; or
The use of information in:
An administrative proceeding initiated by the Department; or
A judicial proceeding.
